content.description: Zig-zag up the shattered slab between the obvious right-facing corner on the left and the obvious left-facing corner on the right. The angle lowers toward the top with the crux on a short blank section just below the highest horizontal crack. If leading, the crux is protected by a large cam or hex just below your feet. The anchor is shared with the left variation of Right Corner.
content.protection: 1 set of cams and 1 set of nuts up to 2.5 inches

content.description: Climb the obvious left-facing corner. The 5.7 crux is moving left around a bulge about a third of the way up. Near the top there are two options: either continue right up the corner to a set of bolts just right of the pinnacles summit (1 star), or traverse left across the highest horizontal crack and continue up the slab to a pair of bolts on the ridge just left of the pinnacles summit (3 stars). The traverse to the left is exposed but easier than it appears (5.6), and the anchor is much better for setting up a top rope. Warning: do not use the rusty, partially pulled bolts with chains on the face below the top of the pinnacle.
content.protection: 1 set of cams up to 2 inches.

content.description:
NOTE: THE RIGHT SIDE OF AN OVERHANGING BLOCK FELL DURING THE WINTER OF 2017-2018 (see photos). Start at Left Corner. About 15 feet up move left and climb the jagged arete (formerly a crack) where the block right of the edge fell, then wander up the face just left of the arete toward the bolt, traverse left below the bolt and climb the face several feet left of the bolt to an anchor at the top. The new crux comprises a few thin face moves just above the overhang.

"Jagged Edge" variation 5.10c: climb the overhanging right side of the jagged arete.

FOR THOSE WONDERING WHAT YOU MISSED BEFORE THE OVERHANGING BLOCK FELL, HERE IS MY ORIGINAL DESCRIPTION: Start at the obvious right-facing arch. About 15 feet up, climb left over the overhanging arch on good holds in a crack on the face, then wander up the face to the left of Bolt Route or finish on Bolt Route. If leading, the overhang is well protected by a double sling around the large block beneath the arch and a small cam in a solid crack between hand holds on the face. The overhang is much easier than it appears. The anchor is shared with Left Corner.
content.protection: 1 set of cams up to 2 inches. Rappel off a double bolt anchor with rappel rings.

content.description: On the smaller right-hand wall (opposite the major climbs), climb the short, dirty face just right of the obvious crack 25 feet to the base of a big Douglas Fir. The climb is a boulder problem surmounting a bulge, followed by easy but dirty face climbing.
content.protection: None. A top-rope anchor can be set up from the Douglas Fir at the top.
content.location: Face just right of the obvious crack on the smaller right-hand wall (opposite the major climbs).

content.description: On the smaller right-hand wall (opposite the major climbs), climb the short, dirty crack 25 feet to the base of a big Douglas Fir.
content.protection: Two or three large cams (2-4 inches) if leading; otherwise, set up a top-rope anchor around the big Douglas Fir.
content.location: Obvious crack on the smaller right-hand wall (opposite the major climbs).

content.description: The climb is on the far right edge of the headwall to the right of Right Corner. Start in the mine shaft underneath the obvious wood brace [no longer present, see comment below] in the chimney. Chimney up to the wood brace, sling it, and then climb up and left to the base of the dihedral. Step to the right and climb the well-protected hand cracks to the top. Belay from either a tree stump or a larger tree trunk.
content.protection: A long sling for the wood brace and a few small to medium cams. If top-roping, long slings or a short rope are needed for anchoring to a tree or tree stump 15 feet from the edge.
content.location: The farthest climb on the right, starting beneath the obvious wood brace in the mine shaft.

content.description: Start at the obvious right-facing arch and continue up the right-facing corner to a spacious ledge with bolts and chains. The crux is surmounting a short and steep blank section near the top, with a long reach up and left (harder for short climbers), with protection just below your feet.
content.protection: 1 set of cams and 1 set of nuts up to 2 inches

content.description: The climb is in the center of the headwall to the right of Right Corner. Climb the blocky wall to the right of Right Corner and mantel to a sloping ledge. Climb a few moves to a narrower sloping ledge, then move right to a large, obvious crack system on the upper headwall. Climb the well-protected hand crack which diagonals left, then right, to the top.
content.protection: 1 set of cams; nuts may also be used. Belay anchor requires gear, but may be backed up by two old bolts to the left.
content.location: Enter the narrower constriction in the gorge and start at the base of the large blocks to the right of Right Corner.

content.description: This climb is just to the right of Right Corner. Climb the blocky wall to the right of Right Corner and mantel to a sloping ledge. Climb a few moves to a narrower sloping ledge, then move left to a fractured seam which begins with an overhanging bulge (crux). Climb the fractured seam to the top, staying a few feet to the right of the arete of Right Corner.
content.protection: 1 set of cams, 1 set of nuts. A marginal small cam placement in the fractured seam protects the crux overhang move at the base of the upper headwall; a large cam can be placed below and right of the overhang to prevent a long, painful fall if the smaller cam fails. Two old bolts on the right side of the summit pinnacle can be used for the anchor but should be backed up by gear.
content.location: Enter the narrower constriction in the gorge and start at the base of the large blocks to the right of Right Corner.

content.description: Climb the 5.7 face and surmount the 5.7 overhang just below and right of the small Douglas Fir. Continue up class 4 to a bolted anchor. There are several options for the start, with the hardest being a 5.8 boulder move up the face. The route is easier (5.6) if you climb up the cracks to the left of the face and bypass the overhang by climbing farther to the right.
content.protection: Cams up to 2". There are only a couple of dubious small cam placements on the face below the overhang. If you move a few feet to the left you can set cams in the obvious crack, where the climbing is easier. The overhang is protected by a medium-sized cam (or two) in a flaring crack beneath the overhang.
content.location: Descend via rappel from a double bolt anchor with rap rings.

content.description: From the top of a short, triangular-shaped pedestal left of Left Corner, climb up a short 5.6 hand crack and easier broken rock to a small Douglas Fir. From the tree either climb up and left over a short headwall (best finish, 5.6) to a bolted anchor, or traverse right and up (class 3) to a bolted anchor. Beware of some loose rock.
content.protection: Cams up to 1.5", bolted anchor with rap rings.
content.location: Descend via rappel off anchor bolts on Left Corner.

content.description: Traverse left and up into Dynamite Crack.
content.location: Start in right side of small right cave.

content.description: Semi highball crack with rocky landing in cave.
content.location: Main crack center face of cave.

content.description: Stand start lower left next to bad fall zone and traverse up right into the semi highball Dynamite Crack to top out. ~Dangerous.
content.location: Start in the lower left side of the upper cave above/on top of the Mine Crag and just below the main dirt road.

content.description: The climb is on the right side of the headwall to the right of Right Corner, ascending a short but obvious dihedral near the top of wall. Start in the mine shaft underneath the dihedral and climb up blocky rocks to a wide, slanting ledge. Climb the well-protected dihedral which ends with a committing but easy move over a small overhang. Belay from either a tree stump or a larger tree trunk.
content.protection: A few small to medium cams. If top-roping, long slings or a short rope are needed for anchoring to a tree or tree stump 15 feet from the edge.
content.location: Short but obvious dihedral about 30 feet right of Right Corner.

content.description:
This contrived "route" (a variation of Left Corner) is the hardest at Silverado Mine. Start at the obvious right-facing arch and climb halfway up Left Corner to a blank section protected by a single bolt. Climb on small face holds just left of the bolt (5.10c) or right of the bolt (5.10a), avoiding any cracks farther left or right of the bolt, leading to buckets above. The anchor is shared with Left Corner.

Alternative start: climb Overhang 5.9 and finish on Bolt Route 5.10a/c.
content.protection: 1 quick draw for the bolt, 1 set of cams up to 2 inches and 1 set of nuts up to 2 inches.

content.description: From the left side of the triangular pedestal and left of Fir Tree Crack, climb straight up broken rock past a very short crack to a bolted anchor at the top. Beware of some loose rock.
content.protection: Small to medium cams protect the crux halfway up; the first 15' and last 15' are runout but very easy.
content.location: Far left side of the wall. Descend by rappel off two bolts with rap rings.
